caption: Despite its great size, the positioning of this memorial to the American support for France in the First World War can be easily overlooked. On the large plinth stands the lone soldier waving his cap in recognition of his comrades in arms. Luckily the excellent tribute is visible on the tourist bus route.

Excellent monument commemorating American citizens who volunteered their services to France prior to the United States of America's official engagement in the Great War.  The stone sculpture shows French and American soldiers welcoming each other in front of a winged Victory. The bronze statue of an American soldier is based on the likeness of the poet Alan Seeger. Living in Paris when war broke out, Seeger enlisted in the French Foreign legion in August 1914. He was killed in action on the Somme in July 1916.  On both sides of the monument are quotes from Seeger's poems and the rear is a list of over 100 American volunteers killed during the war, most whilst serving with the Foreign Legion, the Lafayette Squadron and the American Field Ambulance Service.  The monument is position next to the square Thomas-Jefferson in the  place des États-Unis. The metro station Georges V is about a 5-10 minute walk.
Friends in need are friends indeed. Monuments for the American volunteers that joined before the USA has joined a great war, this should be never forgotten.
A remarkable testament to the French-American century-long alliance! Besides, the park nearby is a nice picknick spot :)
Good safe place for kids to play

Very pretty American memorial monument of the First World War, in tribute to all these volunteer soldiers who came to fight here in France. It reminds us all of these fighters who came to help within the French army. Very easy to access, very well maintained. To have ...
A very nice statue, and, contrary to what Google Maps says, it is open all the time, since it is a statue.
Monument to American Volunteers during the First World War. Quiet, cozy park. Located on the way from the Arc de Triomphe to the Eiffel Tower.

Commemorative monument to the First World War located in Paris (16th), Place desUnis in Square Thomas-Jefferson. It honors the memory of American volunteers engaged in the French army between 1914 and 1918. On January 21, 1917, an evening of tribute to the American volunteers was organized at the Comédie-Française. During this evening, a public subscription was opened to finance the construction of a monument to American volunteers. It was inaugurated by the President of the Council, Raymond Poincaré, on July 4, 1923.
